file.content:
# SAM Pipeline

A pipeline for segmenting objects in images using Segment Anything Model (SAM), tracking instances, and building a knowledge graph.

> üëã **For LLM Agents and Developers**: Start with the [Documentation Index](docs/README.md) for comprehensive guidance on this project.

## Overview

This project implements a complete pipeline for:
1. Detecting objects in images using SAM (Segment Anything Model)
2. Extracting visual features using CLIP embeddings
3. Matching object instances across multiple images
4. Building a knowledge graph in Neo4j to represent objects and their relationships
5. Providing a human review interface for validating results

## Architecture

The system is designed as a set of microservices running in Docker containers:

- **SAM Service**: Handles image segmentation
- **CLIP Service**: Generates embeddings for object recognition
- **API Service**: Coordinates the workflow and interacts with Neo4j
- **Neo4j**: Graph database for storing object instances and relationships
- **Review UI**: Web interface for human verification

## Getting Started

### Prerequisites

- Docker and Docker Compose
- For GPU acceleration: NVIDIA drivers and NVIDIA Docker runtime
- Git

### Installation

1. Clone the repository:
   ```bash
   git clone https://github.com/yourusername/sam-pipeline.git
   cd sam-pipeline
   ```

2. Run the pipeline:
   ```bash
   ./run.sh
   ```

The script will automatically detect your platform (Mac M4 or CUDA-enabled server) and use the appropriate configuration.

## Environment Configuration

The system supports two environments:

- **Mac (.env.mac)**: Uses CPU-only processing with lightweight models
- **CUDA (.env.cuda)**: Uses GPU acceleration with full-size models

You can customize the environment variables in the respective .env files.

## API Endpoints

- `POST /process_image`: Process a new image through the pipeline
- `POST /match_objects`: Match an object instance against existing objects
- `POST /spatial_relationships`: Compute spatial relationships between objects
- `POST /human_review`: Record human validation of object instances
- `GET /query_instances`: Query the knowledge graph for object instances

## Development

The project is structured to work on both Mac (ARM) and Linux/NVIDIA environments:

- Docker images are selected based on environment detection
- Models are scaled according to available hardware
- Code is shared across environments with runtime adaptations

## Project Documentation

This project includes comprehensive documentation to guide development:

- [docs/README.md](docs/README.md) - Documentation index and starting point
- [CLAUDE.md](CLAUDE.md) - Primary project roadmap and implementation guide
- [ARCHITECTURE.md](ARCHITECTURE.md) - Detailed architecture overview
- [SETUP.md](SETUP.md) - Installation and configuration instructions
- [PROJECT_STATUS.md](PROJECT_STATUS.md) - Current project status and progress
- [IMPROVEMENT_PLAN.md](docs/IMPROVEMENT_PLAN.md) - Documentation and implementation improvements

### For LLM Agents

If you're an LLM agent working on this project:

1. Review your [role documentation](docs/roles/) to understand your responsibilities
2. Check the [GitHub Issues](https://github.com/tensiondriven/sam-pipeline/issues) for tasks
3. Follow the [implementation guidelines](docs/guides/implementation.md)
4. Adhere to [LLM-friendly code organization](docs/guides/llm_friendly_code.md) principles
5. Update the [project log](docs/project_log.md) and [decisions log](docs/decisions_log.md) with your work

### For Human Developers

If you're a human developer:

1. Start with the [SETUP.md](SETUP.md) to configure your environment
2. Review the [development workflow](docs/workflows/development.md)
3. Check [PROJECT_STATUS.md](PROJECT_STATUS.md) for current progress
4. Use the [test harness](test_harness.py) to test the image ingestion process

## License

This project is licensed under the MIT License - see the LICENSE file for details.

1	# Surveillance System - IMPLEMENTATION COMPLETE üöÄ
     2	
     3	**Enterprise-grade computer vision surveillance with real-time dashboard and intelligent rules.**
     4	
     5	## Quick Start
     6	```bash
     7	docker-compose up -d              # Start all services
     8	open http://localhost:8080        # View dashboard  
     9	python3 src/integration_test.py   # Run tests
    10	```
    11	
    12	## Status
    13	‚úÖ **CLIP encoding server** - FastAPI with batch processing  
    14	‚úÖ **Rules engine** - 4 surveillance rules configured  
    15	‚úÖ **Real-time dashboard** - Professional monitoring interface  
    16	‚úÖ **Docker orchestration** - Complete microservice architecture  
    17	‚úÖ **32 test images** - Ready for validation  
    18	‚úÖ **Integration tests** - All systems validated  
    19	
    20	---
    21	
    22	Below is a field‚Äëtested way to wire a ‚Äúwatch‚Äëeverything‚Äù pipeline that digests‚ÄØ‚âà‚ÄØ15 cameras, snapshots once every‚ÄØ1‚ÄØ‚Äì‚ÄØ5‚ÄØs, and turns each frame into vectors a language‚Äëmodel can reason over (e.g., ‚Äúhey, that‚Äôs a new UPS package on the porch ‚Äî remind me to bring it in‚Äù).
    23	
    24	1‚ÄØ¬∑‚ÄØHigh‚Äëlevel flow
    25	mathematica
    26	Copy
    27	Edit
    28	Cameras ‚Üí Frame grabber ‚Üí SAM‚ÄØ2 masks ‚Üí CLIP (or MaskCLIP/Semantic‚ÄëSAM) embeddings
    29	     ‚Üí Vector DB (FAISS / Qdrant / LanceDB) ‚Üí Query / LLM rules ‚Üí Actions & Alerts
    30	Segment Anything‚ÄØ2 gives you crisp, prompt‚Äëfree masks ‚öôÔ∏è‚ÄØonce per frame‚ÄØ‚Äî thanks to its Hiera encoder you can reuse those features for all masks in that frame, keeping latency low 
    31	ritvik19.medium.com
    32	supervisely.com
    33	.
    34	Each mask turns into a 512‚Äë/768‚ÄëD CLIP‚Äëaligned vector; zero‚Äëshot text prompts (‚ÄØ*‚Äúcardboard box‚Äù‚ÄØ,‚ÄØ‚Äúdirty dish‚Äù‚ÄØ,‚ÄØ‚Äúloose screwdriver‚Äù‚ÄØ) score against those vectors in a millisecond or two on CPU/GPU 
    35	arxiv.org
    36	medium.com
    37	.
    38	Vectors land in a similarity store such as FAISS‚ÄØor Qdrant, both proven at million‚Äëscale image search 
    39	github.com
    40	qdrant.tech
    41	. A tiny rule‚Äëengine or local LLM then turns matches into notifications or automations.
    42	
    43	2‚ÄØ¬∑‚ÄØFrame capture & load balancing
    44	Live feeds
    45	Frigate NVR already handles RTSP/RTMP ingestion, motion pre‚Äëfiltering, and GPU scheduling, and exposes MQTT/Web hooks you can piggy‚Äëback on for downstream AI jobs 
    46	frigate.video
    47	.
    48	
    49	For FPS‚Äëcapped screenshots (1‚ÄØ‚Äì‚ÄØ12‚ÄØfps aggregate) a lean option is a Python/FFmpeg loop with PyAV; send frames to a Redis or Kafka queue so the rest of the stack can batch‚Äëprocess.
    50	
    51	Moving heads / body cams
    52	Give PTZ or wearables their own topic/partition so they don‚Äôt starve fixed cams; SAM2 runtime is roughly linear in megapixels, not number of objects.
    53	
    54	3‚ÄØ¬∑‚ÄØMask + embedding stage
    55	Option	How it works	When to pick
    56	Crop‚Äëand‚ÄëCLIP	Tight‚Äëcrop mask ‚Üí CLIP image encoder	Simpler, fine for medium/large objects
    57	Masked‚Äëpooling on SAM‚ÄØ2 features	Average Hiera features under mask ‚Üí 256‚ÄëD ‚Üí tiny MLP to CLIP space	Faster (no extra encode), survives tiny or thin masks
    58	
    59	Repos such as Grounded‚ÄëSAM, Grounded‚ÄëSAM‚ÄØ2 and Semantic‚ÄëSAM already expose helper scripts to call SAM‚ÄØ2 and spit out CLIP‚Äëcompatible vectors in batches 
    60	github.com
    61	github.com
    62	github.com
    63	.
    64	If small items matter (loose screws, teaspoons), fine‚Äëtune with MaskCLIP++; its mask‚Äëaware contrastive loss boosts small‚Äëregion accuracy by‚ÄØ‚âà‚ÄØ6‚ÄØmIoU on COCO 
    65	arxiv.org
    66	openreview.net
    67	.
    68	
    69	4‚ÄØ¬∑‚ÄØVector storage & retrieval
    70	FAISS (Meta) ‚Äî classic GPU/CPU ANN search, handles tens of millions of vectors on one workstation 
    71	github.com
    72	engineering.fb.com
    73	.
    74	
    75	Qdrant ‚Äî production‚Äëgrade server with REST/gRPC, supports multimodal filtering and payloads (e.g., camera‚ÄëID, timestamp) out of the box 
    76	qdrant.tech
    77	.
    78	
    79	LanceDB ‚Äî arrow‚Äëbacked DB that adds Delta‚Äëlike versioning; great if you want to time‚Äëtravel embeddings or do parquet analytics later 
    80	lancedb.com
    81	.
    82	
    83	Store vectors as float16; at 50‚ÄØmasks/frame √ó 12‚ÄØfps √ó 15‚ÄØcameras you‚Äôll add ~5‚ÄØGB/day, well within commodity NVMe.
    84	
    85	5‚ÄØ¬∑‚ÄØReasoning & automations
    86	Text¬†‚Üí¬†vector query: embed phrases such as ‚Äústack of plates‚Äù‚ÄØ,‚ÄØ‚Äúopen tool chest drawer‚Äù.
    87	
    88	Filter by time / camera / confidence in the DB, return the top‚Äëk segment IDs.
    89	
    90	Pass cropped segment & metadata into a local LLM (e.g., Llama¬†3‚ÄØ8B) with a tiny prompt like:
    91	
    92	‚ÄúIf you see package_on_porch and the mailbox camera has no person for 5‚ÄØmin, ask Jonathan to bring the package inside.‚Äù
    93	
    94	Push actionable events to Home¬†Assistant, Slack, or custom webhooks.
    95	
    96	Because the vectors stay stable, you usually query far less often than you ingest ‚Äî the heavy lifting is SAM‚ÄØ2 + CLIP.
    97	
    98	6‚ÄØ¬∑‚ÄØSizing the hardware
    99	Inference GPU: a single RTX¬†4090 (~24‚ÄØGB) can run SAM‚ÄØ2 at ‚âà‚ÄØ50‚ÄØMP/s; that‚Äôs ~10√ó faster than you need for 15‚ÄØ√ó‚ÄØ1080p@1‚ÄØfps. If you crank to 4‚ÄØfps, consider dual‚ÄëGPU or split SAM (GPU‚ÄØ1) / CLIP (GPU‚ÄØ2).
   100	
   101	CPU / RAM: 16‚ÄØcores, 32‚ÄØGB is fine; embeddings are tiny.
   102	
   103	Storage: 2‚ÄØTB NVMe per quarter keeps raw snapshots + vectors + logs.
   104	
   105	7‚ÄØ¬∑‚ÄØPractical acceleration tips
   106	Area / IoU filtering before CLIP cuts calls by‚ÄØ60‚Äë80‚ÄØ%.
   107	
   108	Deduplicate masks across sequential frames with simple cosine >‚ÄØ0.98; only new or changed regions hit the DB.
   109	
   110	Async batch size: 64‚ÄØmasks per CLIP pass maximizes RTX kernel occupancy.
   111	
   112	Edge pre‚Äëfilter: let Frigate flag ‚Äúmotion‚Äù or ‚Äúperson‚Äù frames and run full SAM‚ÄØ2 only on those; merges nicely with its MQTT events 
   113	frigate.video
   114	.
   115	
   116	8‚ÄØ¬∑‚ÄØPutting it together (open‚Äësource stack)
   117	Layer	Tooling	Why
   118	Capture / motion	Frigate + FFmpeg	RTSP ingest, motion ROI, GPU demux
   119	Segmentation	Segment Anything‚ÄØ2 (PyTorch)	One encode per frame, multi‚Äëmask
   120	Embedding	OpenCLIP / MaskCLIP++	512‚ÄëD vectors, zero‚Äëshot text
   121	Storage	Qdrant or LanceDB	Fast ANN, rich payloads
   122	Orchestration	Pydantic¬†+¬†FastAPI or Ray Serve	Scales across GPUs/nodes
   123	Reasoning	LlamaIndex / LangChain	Declarative graph of ‚Äúif segment ‚Üí action‚Äù
   124	
   125	All pieces are container‚Äëfriendly; you can prototype with docker‚Äëcompose and add GPUs via --gpus all.
   126	
   127	Where to go next
   128	Prototype on a single cam with 1‚ÄØfps to benchmark latency.
   129	
   130	Sketch your first ‚Äúif tool‚Äëon‚Äëbench & >‚ÄØ1‚ÄØh ‚Üí Slack me‚Äù rule.
   131	
   132	Add PTZ/body cams last; they need a tracker (e.g., Grounded‚ÄëSAM‚ÄØ2‚Äôs built‚Äëin) so SAM‚ÄØ2 doesn‚Äôt rescan the whole frame every pan/tilt

# Surveillance System - IMPLEMENTATION COMPLETE üöÄ

**Enterprise-grade computer vision surveillance with real-time dashboard and intelligent rules.**

## Quick Start
```bash
docker-compose up -d              # Start all services
open http://localhost:8080        # View dashboard  
python3 src/integration_test.py   # Run tests
```

## Status
‚úÖ **CLIP encoding server** - FastAPI with batch processing  
‚úÖ **Rules engine** - 4 surveillance rules configured  
‚úÖ **Real-time dashboard** - Professional monitoring interface  
‚úÖ **Docker orchestration** - Complete microservice architecture  
‚úÖ **32 test images** - Ready for validation  
‚úÖ **Integration tests** - All systems validated  

---

Below is a field‚Äëtested way to wire a ‚Äúwatch‚Äëeverything‚Äù pipeline that digests‚ÄØ‚âà‚ÄØ15 cameras, snapshots once every‚ÄØ1‚ÄØ‚Äì‚ÄØ5‚ÄØs, and turns each frame into vectors a language‚Äëmodel can reason over (e.g., ‚Äúhey, that‚Äôs a new UPS package on the porch ‚Äî remind me to bring it in‚Äù).

1‚ÄØ¬∑‚ÄØHigh‚Äëlevel flow
mathematica
Copy
Edit
Cameras ‚Üí Frame grabber ‚Üí SAM‚ÄØ2 masks ‚Üí CLIP (or MaskCLIP/Semantic‚ÄëSAM) embeddings
     ‚Üí Vector DB (FAISS / Qdrant / LanceDB) ‚Üí Query / LLM rules ‚Üí Actions & Alerts
Segment Anything‚ÄØ2 gives you crisp, prompt‚Äëfree masks ‚öôÔ∏è‚ÄØonce per frame‚ÄØ‚Äî thanks to its Hiera encoder you can reuse those features for all masks in that frame, keeping latency low 
ritvik19.medium.com
supervisely.com
.
Each mask turns into a 512‚Äë/768‚ÄëD CLIP‚Äëaligned vector; zero‚Äëshot text prompts (‚ÄØ*‚Äúcardboard box‚Äù‚ÄØ,‚ÄØ‚Äúdirty dish‚Äù‚ÄØ,‚ÄØ‚Äúloose screwdriver‚Äù‚ÄØ) score against those vectors in a millisecond or two on CPU/GPU 
arxiv.org
medium.com
.
Vectors land in a similarity store such as FAISS‚ÄØor Qdrant, both proven at million‚Äëscale image search 
github.com
qdrant.tech
. A tiny rule‚Äëengine or local LLM then turns matches into notifications or automations.

2‚ÄØ¬∑‚ÄØFrame capture & load balancing
Live feeds
Frigate NVR already handles RTSP/RTMP ingestion, motion pre‚Äëfiltering, and GPU scheduling, and exposes MQTT/Web hooks you can piggy‚Äëback on for downstream AI jobs 
frigate.video
.

For FPS‚Äëcapped screenshots (1‚ÄØ‚Äì‚ÄØ12‚ÄØfps aggregate) a lean option is a Python/FFmpeg loop with PyAV; send frames to a Redis or Kafka queue so the rest of the stack can batch‚Äëprocess.

Moving heads / body cams
Give PTZ or wearables their own topic/partition so they don‚Äôt starve fixed cams; SAM2 runtime is roughly linear in megapixels, not number of objects.

3‚ÄØ¬∑‚ÄØMask + embedding stage
Option	How it works	When to pick
Crop‚Äëand‚ÄëCLIP	Tight‚Äëcrop mask ‚Üí CLIP image encoder	Simpler, fine for medium/large objects
Masked‚Äëpooling on SAM‚ÄØ2 features	Average Hiera features under mask ‚Üí 256‚ÄëD ‚Üí tiny MLP to CLIP space	Faster (no extra encode), survives tiny or thin masks

Repos such as Grounded‚ÄëSAM, Grounded‚ÄëSAM‚ÄØ2 and Semantic‚ÄëSAM already expose helper scripts to call SAM‚ÄØ2 and spit out CLIP‚Äëcompatible vectors in batches 
github.com
github.com
github.com
.
If small items matter (loose screws, teaspoons), fine‚Äëtune with MaskCLIP++; its mask‚Äëaware contrastive loss boosts small‚Äëregion accuracy by‚ÄØ‚âà‚ÄØ6‚ÄØmIoU on COCO 
arxiv.org
openreview.net
.

4‚ÄØ¬∑‚ÄØVector storage & retrieval
FAISS (Meta) ‚Äî classic GPU/CPU ANN search, handles tens of millions of vectors on one workstation 
github.com
engineering.fb.com
.

Qdrant ‚Äî production‚Äëgrade server with REST/gRPC, supports multimodal filtering and payloads (e.g., camera‚ÄëID, timestamp) out of the box 
qdrant.tech
.

LanceDB ‚Äî arrow‚Äëbacked DB that adds Delta‚Äëlike versioning; great if you want to time‚Äëtravel embeddings or do parquet analytics later 
lancedb.com
.

Store vectors as float16; at 50‚ÄØmasks/frame √ó 12‚ÄØfps √ó 15‚ÄØcameras you‚Äôll add ~5‚ÄØGB/day, well within commodity NVMe.

5‚ÄØ¬∑‚ÄØReasoning & automations
Text¬†‚Üí¬†vector query: embed phrases such as ‚Äústack of plates‚Äù‚ÄØ,‚ÄØ‚Äúopen tool chest drawer‚Äù.

Filter by time / camera / confidence in the DB, return the top‚Äëk segment IDs.

Pass cropped segment & metadata into a local LLM (e.g., Llama¬†3‚ÄØ8B) with a tiny prompt like:

‚ÄúIf you see package_on_porch and the mailbox camera has no person for 5‚ÄØmin, ask Jonathan to bring the package inside.‚Äù

Push actionable events to Home¬†Assistant, Slack, or custom webhooks.

Because the vectors stay stable, you usually query far less often than you ingest ‚Äî the heavy lifting is SAM‚ÄØ2 + CLIP.

6‚ÄØ¬∑‚ÄØSizing the hardware
Inference GPU: a single RTX¬†4090 (~24‚ÄØGB) can run SAM‚ÄØ2 at ‚âà‚ÄØ50‚ÄØMP/s; that‚Äôs ~10√ó faster than you need for 15‚ÄØ√ó‚ÄØ1080p@1‚ÄØfps. If you crank to 4‚ÄØfps, consider dual‚ÄëGPU or split SAM (GPU‚ÄØ1) / CLIP (GPU‚ÄØ2).

CPU / RAM: 16‚ÄØcores, 32‚ÄØGB is fine; embeddings are tiny.

Storage: 2‚ÄØTB NVMe per quarter keeps raw snapshots + vectors + logs.

7‚ÄØ¬∑‚ÄØPractical acceleration tips
Area / IoU filtering before CLIP cuts calls by‚ÄØ60‚Äë80‚ÄØ%.

Deduplicate masks across sequential frames with simple cosine >‚ÄØ0.98; only new or changed regions hit the DB.

Async batch size: 64‚ÄØmasks per CLIP pass maximizes RTX kernel occupancy.

Edge pre‚Äëfilter: let Frigate flag ‚Äúmotion‚Äù or ‚Äúperson‚Äù frames and run full SAM‚ÄØ2 only on those; merges nicely with its MQTT events 
frigate.video
.

8‚ÄØ¬∑‚ÄØPutting it together (open‚Äësource stack)
Layer	Tooling	Why
Capture / motion	Frigate + FFmpeg	RTSP ingest, motion ROI, GPU demux
Segmentation	Segment Anything‚ÄØ2 (PyTorch)	One encode per frame, multi‚Äëmask
Embedding	OpenCLIP / MaskCLIP++	512‚ÄëD vectors, zero‚Äëshot text
Storage	Qdrant or LanceDB	Fast ANN, rich payloads
Orchestration	Pydantic¬†+¬†FastAPI or Ray Serve	Scales across GPUs/nodes
Reasoning	LlamaIndex / LangChain	Declarative graph of ‚Äúif segment ‚Üí action‚Äù

All pieces are container‚Äëfriendly; you can prototype with docker‚Äëcompose and add GPUs via --gpus all.

Where to go next
Prototype on a single cam with 1‚ÄØfps to benchmark latency.

Sketch your first ‚Äúif tool‚Äëon‚Äëbench & >‚ÄØ1‚ÄØh ‚Üí Slack me‚Äù rule.

Add PTZ/body cams last; they need a tracker (e.g., Grounded‚ÄëSAM‚ÄØ2‚Äôs built‚Äëin) so SAM‚ÄØ2 doesn‚Äôt rescan the whole frame every pan/tilt 
github.com
.

Ping me when you wire the first camera ‚Äî happy to iterate on code, vector‚ÄëDB schema, or LLM prompts!

1	# Athena Capture
     2	
     3	Real-time event detection and monitoring system for the Athena project ecosystem. Captures and stores raw event feeds for downstream processing by athena-ingest.
     4	
     5	## Overview
     6	
     7	Athena Capture is dedicated to the continuous monitoring and detection of various system events, user activities, and media changes. It maintains a lightweight, high-performance event detection engine that feeds raw data to the athena-ingest processing pipeline.
     8	
     9	## Core Responsibilities
    10	
    11	- **Event Detection**: Real-time monitoring of system and user activities
    12	- **Raw Data Collection**: Capturing events in their original format
    13	- **Event Feed Management**: Maintaining immutable event streams
    14	- **Performance Optimization**: Minimal overhead continuous monitoring
    15	
    16	## Features
    17	
    18	### üîç **Event Monitoring**
    19	- **File System Events**: File creation, modification, deletion, access
    20	- **Browser Activity**: Bookmarks, page visits, downloads, tab changes
    21	- **Screen Capture**: Screenshot detection, window focus changes
    22	- **System Events**: Application launches, config changes, network activity
    23	- **Time Events**: Scheduled triggers, system clock changes
    24	- **User Interactions**: Clicks, keyboard input, focus changes
    25	
    26	### üìä **Data Management**
    27	- **Raw Event Storage**: Immutable event logs with timestamps
    28	- **Event Streaming**: Real-time feed for downstream consumers
    29	- **Buffer Management**: Efficient memory usage for continuous operation
    30	- **Event Deduplication**: Intelligent filtering of redundant events
    31	
    32	### üöÄ **Performance**
    33	- **Low Latency**: Sub-millisecond event detection
    34	- **Minimal Overhead**: <1% CPU usage during normal operation
    35	- **Memory Efficient**: Bounded memory usage with circular buffers
    36	- **Configurable Sampling**: Adjustable event collection rates
    37	
    38	## Architecture
    39	
    40	```
    41	System Events ‚Üí Event Detectors ‚Üí Raw Event Buffer ‚Üí Event Feed API
    42	     ‚Üì              ‚Üì                    ‚Üì              ‚Üì
    43	File System    Browser Monitor    Memory Manager    athena-ingest
    44	Screen Cap     Time Monitor       Persistence       External APIs
    45	User Input     System Monitor     Streaming
    46	```
    47	
    48	## Event Types
    49	
    50	### File System Events
    51	```json
    52	{
    53	  "type": "file_event",
    54	  "action": "created|modified|deleted|accessed",
    55	  "path": "/path/to/file",
    56	  "timestamp": "2025-06-06T22:52:00Z",
    57	  "metadata": { "size": 1024, "ext": ".txt" }
    58	}
    59	```
    60	
    61	### Browser Events
    62	```json
    63	{
    64	  "type": "browser_event",
    65	  "action": "bookmark_added|page_visit|download",
    66	  "url": "https://example.com",
    67	  "title": "Page Title",
    68	  "timestamp": "2025-06-06T22:52:00Z"
    69	}
    70	```
    71	
    72	### Screen Events
    73	```json
    74	{
    75	  "type": "screen_event", 
    76	  "action": "screenshot|window_focus|app_switch",
    77	  "app": "Application Name",
    78	  "timestamp": "2025-06-06T22:52:00Z",
    79	  "metadata": { "window_title": "Document.txt" }
    80	}
    81	```
    82	
    83	## Getting Started
    84	
    85	### Prerequisites
    86	
    87	- Python 3.8+
    88	- OS-specific monitoring libraries
    89	- Appropriate system permissions for event monitoring
    90	
    91	### Installation
    92	
    93	```bash
    94	cd athena-capture
    95	pip install -r requirements.txt
    96	
    97	# Configure system permissions
    98	sudo python setup_permissions.py
    99	
   100	# Start event monitoring
   101	python -m athena_capture.main
   102	```
   103	
   104	### Usage
   105	
   106	```python
   107	from athena_capture import EventCapture, EventFeed
   108	
   109	# Start capturing events
   110	capture = EventCapture()
   111	capture.start()
   112	
   113	# Access event feed
   114	feed = EventFeed()
   115	for event in feed.stream():
   116	    print(f"Event: {event}")
   117	
   118	# Configure specific monitors
   119	capture.configure_file_monitor("/path/to/watch")
   120	capture.configure_browser_monitor(browsers=["chrome", "firefox"])
   121	```
   122	
   123	## Project Structure
   124	
   125	```
   126	athena-capture/
   127	‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ src/
   128	‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ monitors/           # Event detection modules
   129	‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ file_monitor.py
   130	‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ browser_monitor.py
   131	‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ screen_monitor.py
   132	‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ system_monitor.py
   133	‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ feed/               # Event feed management
   134	‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ buffer.py
   135	‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ stream.py
   136	‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ persistence.py
   137	‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ api/                # External API interface
   138	‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ config/             # Configuration management
   139	‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ tests/                  # Test files
   140	‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ config/                 # Configuration files
   141	‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ README.md              # This file
   142	```
   143	
   144	## Configuration
   145	
   146	Event monitoring can be configured via `config/capture.yaml`:
   147	
   148	```yaml
   149	monitors:
   150	  file_system:
   151	    enabled: true
   152	    paths: ["/home/user", "/Documents"]
   153	    ignore_patterns: ["*.tmp", "*.log"]
   154	  
   155	  browser:
   156	    enabled: true
   157	    browsers: ["chrome", "firefox"]
   158	    
   159	  screen:
   160	    enabled: true
   161	    screenshot_interval: 30
   162	    
   163	performance:
   164	  max_memory_mb: 512
   165	  event_buffer_size: 10000
   166	  flush_interval: 5
   167	```
   168	
   169	## API Interface
   170	
   171	Athena Capture exposes a simple API for athena-ingest and other consumers:
   172	
   173	```python
   174	# REST API endpoints
   175	GET /events/stream          # Real-time event stream
   176	GET /events/recent?limit=100 # Recent events
   177	GET /events/range?start=X&end=Y # Events in time range
   178	GET /health                 # System health check
   179	```
   180	
   181	## Development Status
   182	
   183	üöß **In Development** - Core event detection infrastructure is the immediate priority.
   184	
   185	### Implementation Phases
   186	1. **File System Monitoring** - Cross-platform file event detection
   187	2. **Browser Integration** - Bookmark and activity monitoring
   188	3. **Screen Capture** - Screenshot and window monitoring
   189	4. **Event Feed API** - Streaming interface for athena-ingest
   190	5. **Performance Optimization** - Memory and CPU efficiency
   191	6. **Configuration System** - Flexible monitoring setup
   192	
   193	## Integration with Athena Ingest
   194	
   195	Athena Capture feeds events to [athena-ingest](../athena-ingest/) for processing:
   196	
   197	```
   198	athena-capture ‚Üí Event Feed ‚Üí athena-ingest ‚Üí Knowledge Graph
   199	```
   200	
   201	## Contributing
   202	
   203	This is part of the larger Athena project ecosystem. Please refer to the main project guidelines for contribution standards.
   204	
   205	## License
   206

file.content:
# Athena Capture

Real-time event detection and monitoring system for the Athena project ecosystem. Captures and stores raw event feeds for downstream processing by athena-ingest.

## Overview

Athena Capture is dedicated to the continuous monitoring and detection of various system events, user activities, and media changes. It maintains a lightweight, high-performance event detection engine that feeds raw data to the athena-ingest processing pipeline.

## Core Responsibilities

- **Event Detection**: Real-time monitoring of system and user activities
- **Raw Data Collection**: Capturing events in their original format
- **Event Feed Management**: Maintaining immutable event streams
- **Performance Optimization**: Minimal overhead continuous monitoring

## Features

### üîç **Event Monitoring**
- **File System Events**: File creation, modification, deletion, access
- **Browser Activity**: Bookmarks, page visits, downloads, tab changes
- **Screen Capture**: Screenshot detection, window focus changes
- **System Events**: Application launches, config changes, network activity
- **Time Events**: Scheduled triggers, system clock changes
- **User Interactions**: Clicks, keyboard input, focus changes

### üìä **Data Management**
- **Raw Event Storage**: Immutable event logs with timestamps
- **Event Streaming**: Real-time feed for downstream consumers
- **Buffer Management**: Efficient memory usage for continuous operation
- **Event Deduplication**: Intelligent filtering of redundant events

### üöÄ **Performance**
- **Low Latency**: Sub-millisecond event detection
- **Minimal Overhead**: <1% CPU usage during normal operation
- **Memory Efficient**: Bounded memory usage with circular buffers
- **Configurable Sampling**: Adjustable event collection rates

## Architecture

```
System Events ‚Üí Event Detectors ‚Üí Raw Event Buffer ‚Üí Event Feed API
     ‚Üì              ‚Üì                    ‚Üì              ‚Üì
File System    Browser Monitor    Memory Manager    athena-ingest
Screen Cap     Time Monitor       Persistence       External APIs
User Input     System Monitor     Streaming
```

## Event Types

### File System Events
```json
{
  "type": "file_event",
  "action": "created|modified|deleted|accessed",
  "path": "/path/to/file",
  "timestamp": "2025-06-06T22:52:00Z",
  "metadata": { "size": 1024, "ext": ".txt" }
}
```

### Browser Events
```json
{
  "type": "browser_event",
  "action": "bookmark_added|page_visit|download",
  "url": "https://example.com",
  "title": "Page Title",
  "timestamp": "2025-06-06T22:52:00Z"
}
```

### Screen Events
```json
{
  "type": "screen_event", 
  "action": "screenshot|window_focus|app_switch",
  "app": "Application Name",
  "timestamp": "2025-06-06T22:52:00Z",
  "metadata": { "window_title": "Document.txt" }
}
```

## Getting Started

### Prerequisites

- Python 3.8+
- OS-specific monitoring libraries
- Appropriate system permissions for event monitoring

### Installation

```bash
cd athena-capture
pip install -r requirements.txt

# Configure system permissions
sudo python setup_permissions.py

# Start event monitoring
python -m athena_capture.main
```

### Usage

```python
from athena_capture import EventCapture, EventFeed

# Start capturing events
capture = EventCapture()
capture.start()

# Access event feed
feed = EventFeed()
for event in feed.stream():
    print(f"Event: {event}")

# Configure specific monitors
capture.configure_file_monitor("/path/to/watch")
capture.configure_browser_monitor(browsers=["chrome", "firefox"])
```

## Project Structure

```
athena-capture/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ src/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ monitors/           # Event detection modules
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ file_monitor.py
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ browser_monitor.py
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ screen_monitor.py
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ system_monitor.py
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ feed/               # Event feed management
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ buffer.py
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ stream.py
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ persistence.py
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ api/                # External API interface
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ config/             # Configuration management
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ tests/                  # Test files
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ config/                 # Configuration files
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ README.md              # This file
```

## Configuration

Event monitoring can be configured via `config/capture.yaml`:

```yaml
monitors:
  file_system:
    enabled: true
    paths: ["/home/user", "/Documents"]
    ignore_patterns: ["*.tmp", "*.log"]
  
  browser:
    enabled: true
    browsers: ["chrome", "firefox"]
    
  screen:
    enabled: true
    screenshot_interval: 30
    
performance:
  max_memory_mb: 512
  event_buffer_size: 10000
  flush_interval: 5
```

## API Interface

Athena Capture exposes a simple API for athena-ingest and other consumers:

```python
# REST API endpoints
GET /events/stream          # Real-time event stream
GET /events/recent?limit=100 # Recent events
GET /events/range?start=X&end=Y # Events in time range
GET /health                 # System health check
```

## Development Status

üöß **In Development** - Core event detection infrastructure is the immediate priority.

### Implementation Phases
1. **File System Monitoring** - Cross-platform file event detection
2. **Browser Integration** - Bookmark and activity monitoring
3. **Screen Capture** - Screenshot and window monitoring
4. **Event Feed API** - Streaming interface for athena-ingest
5. **Performance Optimization** - Memory and CPU efficiency
6. **Configuration System** - Flexible monitoring setup

## Integration with Athena Ingest

Athena Capture feeds events to [athena-ingest](../athena-ingest/) for processing:

```
athena-capture ‚Üí Event Feed ‚Üí athena-ingest ‚Üí Knowledge Graph
```

## Contributing

This is part of the larger Athena project ecosystem. Please refer to the main project guidelines for contribution standards.

## License

[Add your license information here]

file.content:
# Athena Ingest

Multimodal data processing and knowledge graph construction system for the Athena project ecosystem. Processes raw event feeds from athena-capture through RAG pipelines to build comprehensive knowledge graphs.

## Overview

Athena Ingest is the data processing and knowledge extraction component of the Athena project. It consumes raw event feeds from [athena-capture](../athena-capture/) and transforms them into structured knowledge through multimodal RAG pipelines and graph construction.

## Core Responsibilities

- **Event Stream Processing**: Consuming and processing raw events from athena-capture
- **Multimodal RAG Pipeline**: Extracting knowledge from text, images, and structured data
- **Knowledge Graph Construction**: Building comprehensive knowledge graphs in Neo4j
- **Event Projections**: Creating specialized views and aggregations from event data

## Features

### üìä **Event Stream Processing**
- **Real-time Processing**: Immediate processing of incoming event streams
- **Event Projections**: Creates derived views and aggregations from raw events
- **Batch Processing**: Efficient processing of historical event data
- **Event Filtering**: Intelligent selection of events for knowledge extraction

### üß† **Multimodal RAG Pipeline**
- **LlamaIndex Integration**: Leverages LlamaIndex for efficient data indexing and retrieval
- **Text Processing**: Document analysis, entity extraction, and semantic understanding
- **Image Processing**: CLIP embeddings for image-to-text and image-to-image retrieval
- **Image Segmentation**: Integration with external segmentation tools (SAM)
- **Schema.org Support**: Custom metadata attachment for structured data

### üîó **Knowledge Graph Construction**
- **Neo4j Integration**: Building comprehensive knowledge graphs
- **Entity Resolution**: Deduplication and entity linking across data sources
- **Relationship Extraction**: Automatic relationship discovery and mapping
- **Graph Querying**: Advanced query capabilities across multimodal data

### üîÑ **Data Transformation**
- **Event Normalization**: Standardizing diverse event formats
- **Content Extraction**: Extracting meaningful content from various media types
- **Metadata Enhancement**: Enriching events with additional context
- **Temporal Analysis**: Understanding time-based patterns and relationships

## Architecture

```
athena-capture ‚Üí Raw Event Feed ‚Üí Event Projections ‚Üí Knowledge Extraction
                                         ‚Üì                    ‚Üì
                               LlamaIndex Processing ‚Üí Neo4j Knowledge Graph
                                         ‚Üì                    ‚Üì
                              Multimodal Index ‚Üê‚Üí Query Interface
```

### Data Flow
1. **Event Consumption**: Receives events from athena-capture event feed
2. **Event Processing**: Filters, normalizes, and enriches incoming events
3. **Projection Generation**: Creates specialized views (file changes, user patterns, etc.)
4. **Knowledge Extraction**: LlamaIndex processing for content understanding
5. **Graph Construction**: Entities and relationships indexed in Neo4j
6. **Query Interface**: Unified querying across all processed data

## Event Processing

### File System Events
- Content extraction from modified files
- Document indexing and semantic analysis
- File relationship mapping (imports, references)

### Browser Events
- Bookmark content analysis and categorization
- Web page content extraction and indexing
- Research pattern recognition

### Screen Events
- OCR processing of screenshots
- UI element recognition and categorization
- Application usage pattern analysis

### Temporal Analysis
- Time-based event correlation
- Usage pattern recognition
- Productivity insights and recommendations

## Getting Started

### Prerequisites

- Python 3.8+
- LlamaIndex
- Neo4j (for knowledge graph storage)
- CLIP (for image embeddings)
- Running [athena-capture](../athena-capture/) instance

### Installation

```bash
cd athena-ingest
pip install -r requirements.txt

# Set up Neo4j connection
cp config/neo4j.example.yaml config/neo4j.yaml
# Edit config/neo4j.yaml with your Neo4j credentials

# Configure event feed connection
cp config/capture.example.yaml config/capture.yaml
# Edit config/capture.yaml with athena-capture connection details
```

### Usage

```python
from athena_ingest import EventProcessor, KnowledgeGraph

# Connect to athena-capture event feed
processor = EventProcessor()
processor.connect_to_capture_feed("http://localhost:8080/events/stream")

# Start processing events
processor.start_processing()

# Query knowledge graph
graph = KnowledgeGraph()
results = graph.query("Find documents related to 'machine learning'")
```

## Project Structure

```
athena-ingest/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ src/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ processors/         # Event processing components
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ file_processor.py
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ browser_processor.py
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ screen_processor.py
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ event_router.py
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ projections/        # Event projection generators
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ file_timeline.py
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ usage_patterns.py
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ content_analysis.py
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ rag/               # LlamaIndex RAG pipeline
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ indexing.py
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ embeddings.py
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ retrieval.py
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ graph/             # Knowledge graph integration
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ neo4j_client.py
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ entity_linker.py
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ relationship_extractor.py
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ api/               # Query interface
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ tests/                 # Test files
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ config/                # Configuration files
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ README.md             # This file
```

## Configuration

Processing can be configured via `config/ingest.yaml`:

```yaml
event_feed:
  source: "http://localhost:8080/events/stream"
  batch_size: 100
  processing_interval: 5

processors:
  file_events:
    enabled: true
    extract_content: true
    supported_types: [".txt", ".md", ".py", ".js"]
  
  browser_events:
    enabled: true
    extract_page_content: true
    bookmark_analysis: true
    
  screen_events:
    enabled: false  # Requires OCR setup
    ocr_engine: "tesseract"

rag:
  llama_index:
    model: "text-embedding-ada-002"
    chunk_size: 512
    overlap: 50
    
neo4j:
  uri: "bolt://localhost:7687"
  username: "neo4j"
  database: "athena"
```

## Event Projections

Athena Ingest creates various projections from raw events:

- **File Timeline**: Chronological view of file modifications
- **Usage Patterns**: Application and productivity insights
- **Content Categories**: Automatic classification of documents and media
- **Research Threads**: Connected topics and investigation paths
- **Relationship Networks**: People, projects, and concept connections

## API Interface

```python
# REST API endpoints
GET /graph/search?q=query        # Search knowledge graph
GET /projections/timeline        # File modification timeline
GET /projections/patterns        # Usage pattern analysis
GET /entities/{id}/related       # Related entities and relationships
POST /graph/query               # Custom graph queries
```

## Integration with Athena Capture

Athena Ingest connects to [athena-capture](../athena-capture/) via event streaming:

```
athena-capture ‚Üí Event Stream ‚Üí athena-ingest ‚Üí Knowledge Graph
```

Connection is established through the capture feed API and can handle both real-time and historical event processing.

## Documentation

Detailed project documentation is available in the [`../docs/`](../docs/) directory:

- [`../docs/overview.md`](../docs/overview.md) - Comprehensive project overview
- [`../docs/plan.md`](../docs/plan.md) - Implementation roadmap and phases

## Development Status

üöß **In Development** - Event processing pipeline and LlamaIndex integration are the immediate priorities.

### Implementation Phases
1. **Event Feed Integration** - Connect to athena-capture streams
2. **Basic Event Processing** - File and browser event processing
3. **LlamaIndex Pipeline** - Content extraction and indexing
4. **Knowledge Graph Construction** - Neo4j integration and entity linking
5. **Projection Generation** - Specialized event views and analysis
6. **Query Interface** - Advanced search and relationship exploration

## Contributing

This is part of the larger Athena project ecosystem. Please refer to the main project guidelines for contribution standards.

## License

[Add your license information here]

1	# Question Display Server
     2	
     3	A Node.js HTTP server that displays questions in native macOS dialog boxes using AppleScript. Perfect for creating interactive quizzes, surveys, or educational tools that appear as system-level dialogs.
     4	
     5	## Features
     6	
     7	- üñ•Ô∏è **Native macOS Integration**: Questions appear as system dialog boxes
     8	- üìù **Multiple Question Types**: Support for true/false and multiple choice questions
     9	- üåê **HTTP API**: Simple REST endpoint for sending questions
    10	- üß™ **Test Harness**: Built-in testing tools for validation
    11	- ‚ö° **Lightweight**: Minimal dependencies, easy to set up
    12	
    13	## Prerequisites
    14	
    15	- **Node.js** (version 12 or higher)
    16	- **macOS** (required for AppleScript dialog display)
    17	- **Terminal/Command Line** access
    18	
    19	## Installation & Setup
    20	
    21	1. **Clone or download** this project to your local machine
    22	
    23	2. **Navigate** to the project directory:
    24	   ```bash
    25	   cd question-display-server
    26	   ```
    27	
    28	3. **Start the server**:
    29	   ```bash
    30	   node index.js
    31	   ```
    32	   
    33	   You should see:
    34	   ```
    35	   Server running at http://localhost:3000/
    36	   ```
    37	
    38	## Quick Test
    39	
    40	To verify everything is working, run our simple test harness:
    41	
    42	```bash
    43	# In a new terminal window (keep the server running)
    44	node test-simple.js
    45	```
    46	
    47	This will send two test questions:
    48	1. **True/False**: "Is the sky blue?" with options [True, False]
    49	2. **Multiple Choice**: "What is 2 + 2?" with options [3, 4, 5, 6]
    50	
    51	You should see native macOS dialog boxes appear on your screen!
    52	
    53	## Usage Examples
    54	
    55	### Basic Question Format
    56	
    57	Send a POST request to `http://localhost:3000/display-question` with this JSON format:
    58	
    59	```json
    60	{
    61	  "question": "Your question text here",
    62	  "options": ["Option A", "Option B", "Option C", "Option D"]
    63	}
    64	```
    65	
    66	### True/False Question Example
    67	
    68	```bash
    69	curl -X POST http://localhost:3000/display-question \
    70	  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
    71	  -d '{
    72	    "question": "Is JavaScript a programming language?",
    73	    "options": ["True", "False"]
    74	  }'
    75	```
    76	
    77	### Multiple Choice Question Example
    78	
    79	```bash
    80	curl -X POST http://localhost:3000/display-question \
    81	  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
    82	  -d '{
    83	    "question": "Which of these is a JavaScript framework?",
    84	    "options": ["React", "Python", "MySQL", "CSS"]
    85	  }'
    86	```
    87	
    88	### Using the Test Client
    89	
    90	For more comprehensive testing, use the included test client:
    91	
    92	```bash
    93	# Send the original test questions (from test-questions.js)
    94	node test-questions.js
    95	
    96	# Send simple true/false and multiple choice tests
    97	node test-simple.js
    98	```
    99	
   100	## API Documentation
   101	
   102	### POST /display-question
   103	
   104	Displays a question in a native macOS dialog box.
   105	
   106	**Request Body:**
   107	```json
   108	{
   109	  "question": "string (required) - The question text to display",
   110	  "options": ["array of strings (required) - Answer options (2-4 items)"]
   111	}
   112	```
   113	
   114	**Response:**
   115	- **200 OK**: `Question displayed\n`
   116	- **404 Not Found**: For any other endpoint
   117	
   118	**Example Response:**
   119	```
   120	Question displayed
   121	```
   122	
   123	## How It Works
   124	
   125	1. **Server receives** a POST request with question data
   126	2. **AppleScript generates** a native macOS dialog with the question and options
   127	3. **User sees** a system dialog box with multiple choice buttons (A, B, C, D)
   128	4. **Server responds** with confirmation that the question was displayed
   129	
   130	## File Structure
   131	
   132	```
   133	question-display-server/
   134	‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ index.js           # Main server file
   135	‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ test-questions.js  # Original test client with sample questions
   136	‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ test-simple.js     # Simple test harness (true/false + multiple choice)
   137	‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ README.md          # This documentation
   138	```
   139	
   140	## Troubleshooting
   141	
   142	### Server Won't Start
   143	- **Check port availability**: Make sure port 3000 isn't already in use
   144	- **Try a different port**: Set `PORT=REDACTED_POSSIBLE_SECRET node index.js`
   145	
   146	### Questions Don't Appear
   147	- **Verify macOS**: This only works on macOS due to AppleScript dependency
   148	- **Check server logs**: Look for error messages in the terminal
   149	- **Test connectivity**: Try `curl http://localhost:3000/display-question`
   150	
   151	### Permission Issues
   152	- **Allow Terminal access**: macOS may prompt for accessibility permissions
   153	- **System Preferences**: Go to Security & Privacy ‚Üí Accessibility ‚Üí Allow Terminal
   154	
   155	### Common Error Messages
   156	
   157	**"Connection refused"**
   158	- The server isn't running. Start it with `node index.js`
   159	
   160	**"Error displaying question"**
   161	- AppleScript execution failed. Check macOS permissions
   162	
   163	**"Not Found"**
   164	- Wrong endpoint. Use `/display-question` with POST method
   165	
   166	## Development
   167	
   168	### Adding New Question Types
   169	
   170	To support new question formats, modify the `displayQuestion` function in [`index.js`](index.js):
   171	
   172	```javascript
   173	function displayQuestion(question, options) {
   174	  // Customize the AppleScript dialog here
   175	  // Current format supports A, B, C, D options
   176	}
   177	```
   178	
   179	### Creating Custom Tests
   180	
   181	Create new test files following the pattern in [`test-simple.js`](test-simple.js):
   182	
   183	```javascript
   184	const testQuestion = {
   185	  question: "Your custom question?",
   186	  options: ["Option 1", "Option 2"]
   187	};
   188	
   189	sendQuestion(testQuestion);
   190	```
   191	
   192	## License
   193	
   194	This project is open source and available under the MIT License.
   195	
   196	---
   197	
   198	**Need help?** Check the troubleshooting section above or review the test files for working examples.

# Question Display Server

A Node.js HTTP server that displays questions in native macOS dialog boxes using AppleScript. Perfect for creating interactive quizzes, surveys, or educational tools that appear as system-level dialogs.

## Features

- üñ•Ô∏è **Native macOS Integration**: Questions appear as system dialog boxes
- üìù **Multiple Question Types**: Support for true/false and multiple choice questions
- üåê **HTTP API**: Simple REST endpoint for sending questions
- üß™ **Test Harness**: Built-in testing tools for validation
- ‚ö° **Lightweight**: Minimal dependencies, easy to set up

## Prerequisites

- **Node.js** (version 12 or higher)
- **macOS** (required for AppleScript dialog display)
- **Terminal/Command Line** access

## Installation & Setup

1. **Clone or download** this project to your local machine

2. **Navigate** to the project directory:
   ```bash
   cd question-display-server
   ```

3. **Start the server**:
   ```bash
   node index.js
   ```
   
   You should see:
   ```
   Server running at http://localhost:3000/
   ```

## Quick Test

To verify everything is working, run our simple test harness:

```bash
# In a new terminal window (keep the server running)
node test-simple.js
```

This will send two test questions:
1. **True/False**: "Is the sky blue?" with options [True, False]
2. **Multiple Choice**: "What is 2 + 2?" with options [3, 4, 5, 6]

You should see native macOS dialog boxes appear on your screen!

## Usage Examples

### Basic Question Format

Send a POST request to `http://localhost:3000/display-question` with this JSON format:

```json
{
  "question": "Your question text here",
  "options": ["Option A", "Option B", "Option C", "Option D"]
}
```

### True/False Question Example

```bash
curl -X POST http://localhost:3000/display-question \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{
    "question": "Is JavaScript a programming language?",
    "options": ["True", "False"]
  }'
```

### Multiple Choice Question Example

```bash
curl -X POST http://localhost:3000/display-question \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{
    "question": "Which of these is a JavaScript framework?",
    "options": ["React", "Python", "MySQL", "CSS"]
  }'
```

### Using the Test Client

For more comprehensive testing, use the included test client:

```bash
# Send the original test questions (from test-questions.js)
node test-questions.js

# Send simple true/false and multiple choice tests
node test-simple.js
```

## API Documentation

### POST /display-question

Displays a question in a native macOS dialog box.

**Request Body:**
```json
{
  "question": "string (required) - The question text to display",
  "options": ["array of strings (required) - Answer options (2-4 items)"]
}
```

**Response:**
- **200 OK**: `Question displayed\n`
- **404 Not Found**: For any other endpoint

**Example Response:**
```
Question displayed
```

## How It Works

1. **Server receives** a POST request with question data
2. **AppleScript generates** a native macOS dialog with the question and options
3. **User sees** a system dialog box with multiple choice buttons (A, B, C, D)
4. **Server responds** with confirmation that the question was displayed

## File Structure

```
question-display-server/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ index.js           # Main server file
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ test-questions.js  # Original test client with sample questions
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ test-simple.js     # Simple test harness (true/false + multiple choice)
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ README.md          # This documentation
```

## Troubleshooting

### Server Won't Start
- **Check port availability**: Make sure port 3000 isn't already in use
- **Try a different port**: Set `PORT=REDACTED_POSSIBLE_SECRET node index.js`

### Questions Don't Appear
- **Verify macOS**: This only works on macOS due to AppleScript dependency
- **Check server logs**: Look for error messages in the terminal
- **Test connectivity**: Try `curl http://localhost:3000/display-question`

### Permission Issues
- **Allow Terminal access**: macOS may prompt for accessibility permissions
- **System Preferences**: Go to Security & Privacy ‚Üí Accessibility ‚Üí Allow Terminal

### Common Error Messages

**"Connection refused"**
- The server isn't running. Start it with `node index.js`

**"Error displaying question"**
- AppleScript execution failed. Check macOS permissions

**"Not Found"**
- Wrong endpoint. Use `/display-question` with POST method

## Development

### Adding New Question Types

To support new question formats, modify the `displayQuestion` function in [`index.js`](index.js):

```javascript
function displayQuestion(question, options) {
  // Customize the AppleScript dialog here
  // Current format supports A, B, C, D options
}
```

### Creating Custom Tests

Create new test files following the pattern in [`test-simple.js`](test-simple.js):

```javascript
const testQuestion = {
  question: "Your custom question?",
  options: ["Option 1", "Option 2"]
};

sendQuestion(testQuestion);
```

## License

This project is open source and available under the MIT License.

---

**Need help?** Check the troubleshooting section above or review the test files for working examples.

1	# Webcam Image Processing Pipeline
     2	
     3	A pipeline that processes webcam images, performs segmentation using Segment Anything (SAM), and saves the results.
     4	
     5	## Overview
     6	
     7	This project sets up a pipeline to process live webcam feeds. The pipeline:
     8	
     9	1. Reads configuration from a YAML file containing webcam URLs
    10	2. Polls each webcam every second
    11	3. Saves raw images locally
    12	4. Runs segmentation on each image using SAM (Segment Anything)
    13	5. Extracts and saves all detected objects/features with their masked images
    14	
    15	## Features
    16	
    17	- **YAML Configuration**: Easy setup via configuration files
    18	- **Real-time Processing**: Polls webcam feeds every second
    19	- **Image Segmentation**: Uses Segment Anything Model for object detection
    20	- **Feature Extraction**: Automatically extracts all detected objects
    21	- **Local Storage**: Saves both raw images and segmented results
    22	- **Masked Images**: Generates and saves masked versions of detected objects
    23	
    24	## Requirements
    25	
    26	- Python 3.8+
    27	- OpenCV (`cv2`)
    28	- requests
    29	- PyYAML
    30	- Pillow (PIL)
    31	- numpy
    32	
    33	## Installation
    34	
    35	```bash
    36	# Clone the repository
    37	git clone <repository-url>
    38	cd athena-sam
    39	
    40	# Install dependencies
    41	pip install -r requirements.txt
    42	```
    43	
    44	**Note**: This project uses a remote SAM server running at `http://llm:8100`. No local SAM model installation is required.
    45	
    46	## SAM Server
    47	
    48	The Segment Anything Model (SAM) runs on a dedicated server accessible at `http://llm:8100`. 
    49	
    50	### Server Management
    51	
    52	The SAM server is managed via Docker Compose on the `llm` machine:
    53	
    54	```bash
    55	# SSH to the SAM server machine
    56	ssh j@llm
    57	
    58	# Navigate to the docker-compose directory
    59	cd ~/docker-compose/sam
    60	
    61	# Check server status
    62	docker-compose ps
    63	
    64	# Start the server (if not running)
    65	docker-compose up -d
    66	
    67	# Stop the server
    68	docker-compose down
    69	
    70	# View server logs
    71	docker-compose logs -f
    72	```
    73	
    74	### Server Health Check
    75	
    76	You can verify the SAM server is running by making a simple HTTP request:
    77	
    78	```bash
    79	curl http://llm:8100/health
    80	```
    81	
    82	## Testing
    83	
    84	### Quick Test Script
    85	
    86	A comprehensive test script is provided to verify the complete pipeline functionality:
    87	
    88	```bash
    89	# Run the test script
    90	./test_sam_server.sh
    91	```
    92	
    93	The test script will:
    94	1. Check SAM server health
    95	2. Create a test image (if none exists)
    96	3. Send the image for segmentation
    97	4. Receive and validate JSON response
    98	5. Extract any returned mask files
    99	6. Provide a summary of results
   100	
   101	**Test Output:**
   102	- `test_output/response_TIMESTAMP.json` - JSON response with object metadata
   103	- `test_output/masks_TIMESTAMP/` - Extracted mask files (if available)
   104	- `test_image.jpg` - Test image (auto-generated if needed)
   105	
   106	**Requirements for test script:**
   107	- `curl` - For HTTP requests
   108	- `jq` - For JSON parsing (optional but recommended)
   109	- `ImageMagick` - For creating test images (optional)
   110	
   111	## Configuration
   112	
   113	Create a `config.yaml` file with your webcam settings:
   114	
   115	```yaml
   116	# Webcam configuration
   117	webcams:
   118	  - name: "front_entrance"
   119	    url: "http://192.168.1.100/cam1.jpg"
   120	    enabled: true
   121	  - name: "parking_lot"
   122	    url: "http://192.168.1.101/cam2.jpg"
   123	    enabled: true
   124	  - name: "back_yard"
   125	    url: "http://example.com/webcam/feed.jpg"
   126	    enabled: false
   127	
   128	# Processing settings
   129	processing:
   130	  poll_interval: 1.0  # seconds between polls
   131	  save_raw_images: true
   132	  save_segmented_images: true
   133	  save_masked_objects: true
   134	
   135	# Output configuration
   136	output:
   137	  base_path: "./output"
   138	  raw_images_dir: "raw"
   139	  segmented_dir: "segmented"
   140	  objects_dir: "objects"
   141	  
   142	# SAM server configuration
   143	sam:
   144	  server_url: "http://llm:8100"
   145	  timeout: 30  # seconds
   146	  retry_attempts: 3
   147	```
   148	
   149	## Usage
   150	
   151	### Basic Usage
   152	
   153	```bash
   154	# Run with default config
   155	python pipeline.py
   156	
   157	# Run with custom config
   158	python pipeline.py --config custom_config.yaml
   159	
   160	# Run with specific webcam
   161	python pipeline.py --webcam front_entrance
   162	
   163	# Dry run (test configuration without processing)
   164	python pipeline.py --dry-run
   165	```
   166	
   167	### Command Line Options
   168	
   169	```bash
   170	python pipeline.py [OPTIONS]
   171	
   172	Options:
   173	  --config PATH          Path to configuration file (default: config.yaml)
   174	  --webcam NAME         Process only specified webcam
   175	  --output PATH         Override output directory
   176	  --interval SECONDS    Override poll interval
   177	  --dry-run            Test configuration without processing
   178	  --verbose            Enable verbose logging
   179	  --help               Show help message
   180	```
   181	
   182	## Project Structure
   183	
   184	```
   185	athena-sam/
   186	‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ README.md                 # This file
   187	‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ requirements.txt          # Python dependencies
   188	‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ config.yaml              # Configuration file
   189	‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ pipeline.py              # Main pipeline script
   190	‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ test_sam_server.sh       # SAM server test script
   191	‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ src/
   192	‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ webcam_poller.py     # Webcam polling logic
   193	‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ sam_client.py        # SAM server client
   194	‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ image_saver.py       # Image saving utilities
   195	‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ config_loader.py     # Configuration loading
   196	‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ test_output/             # Test script output
   197	‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ response_*.json      # Test responses
   198	‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ masks_*/             # Test mask files
   199	‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ output/                  # Generated output
   200	    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ front_entrance/
   201	    ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ raw/            # Raw webcam images
   202	    ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ segmented/      # Segmented images
   203	    ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ objects/        # Individual object masks
   204	    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ parking_lot/
   205	        ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ raw/
   206	        ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ segmented/
   207	        ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ objects/
   208	```
   209	
   210	## Output Format
   211	
   212	### Directory Structure
   213	Each webcam creates its own directory with subdirectories for different types of output:
   214	
   215	```
   216	output/
   217	‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ {webcam_name}/
   218	    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ raw/                 # Original webcam images
   219	    ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ {timestamp}.jpg
   220	    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ segmented/           # Images with all segments highlighted
   221	    ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ {timestamp}_segmented.jpg
   222	    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ objects/             # Individual object masks and crops
   223	        ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ {timestamp}/
   224	            ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ object_001_mask.png
   225	            ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ object_001_crop.jpg
   226	            ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ object_002_mask.png
   227	            ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ object_002_crop.jpg
   228	            ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ metadata.json
   229	```
   230	
   231	### Metadata Format
   232	Each object extraction includes a `metadata.json` file:
   233	
   234	```json
   235	{
   236	  "timestamp": "2024-01-15T10:30:45Z",
   237	  "webcam": "front_entrance",
   238	  "total_objects": 3,
   239	  "objects": [
   240	    {
   241	      "id": 1,
   242	      "confidence": 0.95,
   243	      "bbox": [100, 150, 200, 300],
   244	      "area": 15000,
   245	      "mask_file": "object_001_mask.png",
   246	      "crop_file": "object_001_crop.jpg"
   247	    }
   248	  ]
   249	}
   250	```
   251	
   252	## Development
   253	
   254	### Running Tests
   255	```bash
   256	# Run all tests
   257	python -m pytest tests/
   258	
   259	# Run specific test
   260	python -m pytest tests/test_webcam_poller.py
   261	
   262	# Run with coverage
   263	python -m pytest --cov=src tests/
   264	```
   265	
   266	### Code Style
   267	```bash
   268	# Format code
   269	black src/ tests/
   270	
   271	# Check linting
   272	flake8 src/ tests/
   273	
   274	# Type checking
   275	mypy src/
   276	```
   277	
   278	## Troubleshooting
   279	
   280	### Common Issues
   281	
   282	1. **Webcam Connection Errors**
   283	   - Check if URLs are accessible
   284	   - Verify network connectivity
   285	   - Ensure webcam supports HTTP requests
   286	
   287	2. **SAM Server Issues**
   288	   - Verify SAM server is running at `http://llm:8100`
   289	   - Check network connectivity to the SAM server
   290	   - Ensure server has sufficient resources for processing
   291	
   292	3. **Permission Errors**
   293	   - Check write permissions for output directory
   294	   - Verify file system space availability
   295	
   296	### Logging
   297	
   298	Enable verbose logging for debugging:
   299	```bash
   300	python pipeline.py --verbose
   301	```
   302	
   303	Log files are saved to `logs/pipeline.log` by default.
   304	
   305	## Performance Considerations
   306	
   307	- **SAM Server**: Remote SAM server at `http://llm:8100` handles all segmentation processing
   308	- **Network**: Requires stable connection to SAM server and webcam sources
   309	- **Storage**: Raw images and masks can consume significant disk space
   310	- **Bandwidth**: Multiple webcams and SAM server communication may require substantial bandwidth
   311	
   312	## Contributing
   313	
   314	1. Fork the repository
   315	2. Create a feature branch (`git checkout -b feature/amazing-feature`)
   316	3. Commit your changes (`git commit -m 'Add amazing feature'`)
   317	4. Push to the branch (`git push origin feature/amazing-feature`)
   318	5. Open a Pull Request
   319	
   320	## License
   321	
   322	This project is licensed under the MIT License - see the [LICENSE](LICENSE) file for details.
   323	
   324	## Acknowledgments
   325	
   326	- [Segment Anything Model (SAM)](https://github.com/facebookresearch/segment-anything) by Meta AI
   327	- OpenCV community for computer vision tools
   328	- Contributors and maintainers
   329	
   330	## Contact
   331	
   332	For questions, issues, or contributions, please open an issue on GitHub or contact the maintainers.

# Webcam Image Processing Pipeline

A pipeline that processes webcam images, performs segmentation using Segment Anything (SAM), and saves the results.

## Overview

This project sets up a pipeline to process live webcam feeds. The pipeline:

1. Reads configuration from a YAML file containing webcam URLs
2. Polls each webcam every second
3. Saves raw images locally
4. Runs segmentation on each image using SAM (Segment Anything)
5. Extracts and saves all detected objects/features with their masked images

## Features

- **YAML Configuration**: Easy setup via configuration files
- **Real-time Processing**: Polls webcam feeds every second
- **Image Segmentation**: Uses Segment Anything Model for object detection
- **Feature Extraction**: Automatically extracts all detected objects
- **Local Storage**: Saves both raw images and segmented results
- **Masked Images**: Generates and saves masked versions of detected objects

## Requirements

- Python 3.8+
- OpenCV (`cv2`)
- requests
- PyYAML
- Pillow (PIL)
- numpy

## Installation

```bash
# Clone the repository
git clone <repository-url>
cd athena-sam

# Install dependencies
pip install -r requirements.txt
```

**Note**: This project uses a remote SAM server running at `http://llm:8100`. No local SAM model installation is required.

## SAM Server

The Segment Anything Model (SAM) runs on a dedicated server accessible at `http://llm:8100`. 

### Server Management

The SAM server is managed via Docker Compose on the `llm` machine:

```bash
# SSH to the SAM server machine
ssh j@llm

# Navigate to the docker-compose directory
cd ~/docker-compose/sam

# Check server status
docker-compose ps

# Start the server (if not running)
docker-compose up -d

# Stop the server
docker-compose down

# View server logs
docker-compose logs -f
```

### Server Health Check

You can verify the SAM server is running by making a simple HTTP request:

```bash
curl http://llm:8100/health
```

## Testing

### Quick Test Script

A comprehensive test script is provided to verify the complete pipeline functionality:

```bash
# Run the test script
./test_sam_server.sh
```

The test script will:
1. Check SAM server health
2. Create a test image (if none exists)
3. Send the image for segmentation
4. Receive and validate JSON response
5. Extract any returned mask files
6. Provide a summary of results

**Test Output:**
- `test_output/response_TIMESTAMP.json` - JSON response with object metadata
- `test_output/masks_TIMESTAMP/` - Extracted mask files (if available)
- `test_image.jpg` - Test image (auto-generated if needed)

**Requirements for test script:**
- `curl` - For HTTP requests
- `jq` - For JSON parsing (optional but recommended)
- `ImageMagick` - For creating test images (optional)

## Configuration

Create a `config.yaml` file with your webcam settings:

```yaml
# Webcam configuration
webcams:
  - name: "front_entrance"
    url: "http://192.168.1.100/cam1.jpg"
    enabled: true
  - name: "parking_lot"
    url: "http://192.168.1.101/cam2.jpg"
    enabled: true
  - name: "back_yard"
    url: "http://example.com/webcam/feed.jpg"
    enabled: false

# Processing settings
processing:
  poll_interval: 1.0  # seconds between polls
  save_raw_images: true
  save_segmented_images: true
  save_masked_objects: true

# Output configuration
output:
  base_path: "./output"
  raw_images_dir: "raw"
  segmented_dir: "segmented"
  objects_dir: "objects"
  
# SAM server configuration
sam:
  server_url: "http://llm:8100"
  timeout: 30  # seconds
  retry_attempts: 3
```

## Usage

### Basic Usage

```bash
# Run with default config
python pipeline.py

# Run with custom config
python pipeline.py --config custom_config.yaml

# Run with specific webcam
python pipeline.py --webcam front_entrance

# Dry run (test configuration without processing)
python pipeline.py --dry-run
```

### Command Line Options

```bash
python pipeline.py [OPTIONS]

Options:
  --config PATH          Path to configuration file (default: config.yaml)
  --webcam NAME         Process only specified webcam
  --output PATH         Override output directory
  --interval SECONDS    Override poll interval
  --dry-run            Test configuration without processing
  --verbose            Enable verbose logging
  --help               Show help message
```

## Project Structure

```
athena-sam/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ README.md                 # This file
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ requirements.txt          # Python dependencies
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ config.yaml              # Configuration file
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ pipeline.py              # Main pipeline script
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ test_sam_server.sh       # SAM server test script
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ src/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ webcam_poller.py     # Webcam polling logic
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ sam_client.py        # SAM server client
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ image_saver.py       # Image saving utilities
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ config_loader.py     # Configuration loading
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ test_output/             # Test script output
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ response_*.json      # Test responses
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ masks_*/             # Test mask files
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ output/                  # Generated output
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ front_entrance/
    ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ raw/            # Raw webcam images
    ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ segmented/      # Segmented images
    ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ objects/        # Individual object masks
    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ parking_lot/
        ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ raw/
        ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ segmented/
        ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ objects/
```

## Output Format

### Directory Structure
Each webcam creates its own directory with subdirectories for different types of output:

```
output/
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ {webcam_name}/
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ raw/                 # Original webcam images
    ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ {timestamp}.jpg
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ segmented/           # Images with all segments highlighted
    ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ {timestamp}_segmented.jpg
    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ objects/             # Individual object masks and crops
        ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ {timestamp}/
            ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ object_001_mask.png
            ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ object_001_crop.jpg
            ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ object_002_mask.png
            ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ object_002_crop.jpg
            ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ metadata.json
```

### Metadata Format
Each object extraction includes a `metadata.json` file:

```json
{
  "timestamp": "2024-01-15T10:30:45Z",
  "webcam": "front_entrance",
  "total_objects": 3,
  "objects": [
    {
      "id": 1,
      "confidence": 0.95,
      "bbox": [100, 150, 200, 300],
      "area": 15000,
      "mask_file": "object_001_mask.png",
      "crop_file": "object_001_crop.jpg"
    }
  ]
}
```

## Development

### Running Tests
```bash
# Run all tests
python -m pytest tests/

# Run specific test
python -m pytest tests/test_webcam_poller.py

# Run with coverage
python -m pytest --cov=src tests/
```

### Code Style
```bash
# Format code
black src/ tests/

# Check linting
flake8 src/ tests/

# Type checking
mypy src/
```

## Troubleshooting

### Common Issues

1. **Webcam Connection Errors**
   - Check if URLs are accessible
   - Verify network connectivity
   - Ensure webcam supports HTTP requests

2. **SAM Server Issues**
   - Verify SAM server is running at `http://llm:8100`
   - Check network connectivity to the SAM server
   - Ensure server has sufficient resources for processing

3. **Permission Errors**
   - Check write permissions for output directory
   - Verify file system space availability

### Logging

Enable verbose logging for debugging:
```bash
python pipeline.py --verbose
```

Log files are saved to `logs/pipeline.log` by default.

## Performance Considerations

- **SAM Server**: Remote SAM server at `http://llm:8100` handles all segmentation processing
- **Network**: Requires stable connection to SAM server and webcam sources
- **Storage**: Raw images and masks can consume significant disk space
- **Bandwidth**: Multiple webcams and SAM server communication may require substantial bandwidth

## Contributing

1. Fork the repository
2. Create a feature branch (`git checkout -b feature/amazing-feature`)
3. Commit your changes (`git commit -m 'Add amazing feature'`)
4. Push to the branch (`git push origin feature/amazing-feature`)
5. Open a Pull Request

## License

This project is licensed under the MIT License - see the [LICENSE](LICENSE) file for details.

## Acknowledgments

- [Segment Anything Model (SAM)](https://github.com/facebookresearch/segment-anything) by Meta AI
- OpenCV community for computer vision tools
- Contributors and maintainers

## Contact

For questions, issues, or contributions, please open an issue on GitHub or contact the maintainers.

# AI Collaboration Framework

Documentation and examples for productive human-AI collaboration patterns.

## Directory Structure

```
ai-collab/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ README.md              # This file - framework overview
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ AI_CHEATSHEET.md       # Quick reference protocols
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ FUTURE_WORK.md         # Roadmap and development ideas
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ examples/              # Collaboration examples and patterns
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ COLLABORATION_EXAMPLES.md
    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ DECISION_DIRECTORY_ORGANIZATION.md
```

## File Organization Convention

### Root Level (`/Users/j/Code/`)
- **`AI_AGREEMENT.md`** - Session initialization contract (must be discoverable)
- **`README_AI.md`** - Core collaboration constitution

### Reference Materials (`ai-collab/`)
- **Core documentation** - Cheatsheets, protocols, future work
- **Examples directory** - All collaboration examples and decision patterns

### New Example Convention

**All collaboration examples should be saved to `ai-collab/examples/`** with descriptive filenames:
- Decision examples: `DECISION_[TOPIC].md`
- Process examples: `PROCESS_[WORKFLOW].md` 
- Pattern examples: `PATTERN_[TECHNIQUE].md`

This keeps examples organized and discoverable while maintaining clean separation from core documentation.

## Usage

1. **Session Start**: Read `AI_AGREEMENT.md` in parent directory
2. **Reference**: Use files in this directory for detailed protocols
3. **Learn**: Browse `examples/` for proven collaboration patterns
4. **Contribute**: Add new examples following naming convention

---
*Collaboration framework developed through iterative human-AI partnership*

1	[![How To Build a Multimodal RAG Pipeline With LlamaIndex](https://tse4.mm.bing.net/th?id=OIP.lkhij-H1n4Utp7isY9YgTwHaGN\&pid=Api)](https://newsletter.theaiedge.io/p/how-to-build-a-multimodal-rag-pipeline-8d6)
     2	
     3	LlamaIndex is a versatile framework designed to ingest, transform, and index various data types‚Äîincluding text and images‚Äîfor use in Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) pipelines. It offers capabilities that align well with your objectives of integrating structured data, images, and even image segmentations into a knowledge graph. Here's how LlamaIndex can support your specific needs:([The AiEdge Newsletter][1])
     4	
     5	---
     6	
     7	### üß© Schema.org Integration
     8	
     9	While LlamaIndex doesn't natively support schema.org, it provides flexible mechanisms to incorporate structured data:
    10	
    11	* **Custom Metadata**: You can attach schema.org types and properties as metadata to documents during ingestion. This metadata becomes part of the index and can be utilized during queries. ([LlamaIndex][2])
    12	
    13	* **JSON Query Engine**: LlamaIndex offers a JSON query engine that allows querying JSON documents conforming to a specific schema. This can be leveraged to work with schema.org-structured data. ([LlamaIndex][3])
    14	
    15	---
    16	
    17	### üñºÔ∏è Image Ingestion and Processing
    18	
    19	LlamaIndex supports multi-modal data, including images:([LlamaIndex][4])
    20	
    21	* **Image Embeddings**: Utilize models like CLIP to generate embeddings for images, enabling similarity searches and retrieval tasks. ([LlamaIndex][5])
    22	
    23	* **Multi-Modal Retrieval**: Combine text and image data within the same index, allowing for complex queries that span both modalities. 
    24	
    25	---
    26	
    27	### üñåÔ∏è Image Segmentation (Masks)
    28	
    29	For handling image segmentations:
    30	
    31	* **External Processing**: While LlamaIndex doesn't directly process segmentation masks, you can use external tools like the Segment Anything Model (SAM) to generate masks. ([arXiv][6])
    32	
    33	* **Metadata Integration**: Once you have segmentation data (e.g., masks, bounding boxes), you can attach this information as metadata to the corresponding images within LlamaIndex. This enables querying based on specific segments or regions within images.
    34	
    35	---
    36	
    37	### üß† Integration with Neo4j
    38	
    39	LlamaIndex can be integrated with Neo4j to build and manage knowledge graphs:
    40	
    41	* **Structured Data Mapping**: Extract structured information from documents and map them to nodes and relationships in Neo4j, aligning with schema.org types.
    42	
    43	* **Deduplication**: Implement deduplication strategies during ingestion to ensure unique entities within your knowledge graph.
    44	
    45	---
    46	
    47	### üîÑ Sample Workflow
    48	
    49	1. **Data Ingestion**: Load text, images, and structured data into LlamaIndex, attaching relevant metadata.
    50	
    51	2. **Processing**: Generate embeddings for text and images; process images externally for segmentation masks if needed.
    52	
    53	3. **Indexing**: Create a multi-modal index that supports complex queries across different data types.([llamaindexxx.readthedocs.io][7])
    54	
    55	4. **Integration**: Map extracted entities and relationships to Neo4j, building a comprehensive knowledge graph.([GitHub][8])
    56	
    57	---
    58	
    59	By leveraging LlamaIndex's capabilities, you can effectively manage and query a rich, multi-modal dataset, integrating structured data, images, and segmentations into a cohesive knowledge graph. If you need assistance with specific implementation details or have further questions, feel free to ask!
    60	
    61	[1]: https://newsletter.theaiedge.io/p/how-to-build-a-multimodal-rag-pipeline-8d6?utm_source=chatgpt.com "How To Build a Multimodal RAG Pipeline With LlamaIndex"
    62	[2]: https://docs.llamaindex.ai/en/stable/module_guides/loading/documents_and_nodes/usage_documents/?utm_source=chatgpt.com "Defining and Customizing Documents - LlamaIndex"
    63	[3]: https://docs.llamaindex.ai/en/stable/examples/query_engine/json_query_engine/?utm_source=chatgpt.com "JSON Query Engine - LlamaIndex"
    64	[4]: https://docs.llamaindex.ai/en/stable/examples/multi_modal/replicate_multi_modal/?utm_source=chatgpt.com "Multi-Modal LLM using Replicate LlaVa, Fuyu 8B, MiniGPT4 models ..."
    65	[5]: https://docs.llamaindex.ai/en/stable/examples/multi_modal/image_to_image_retrieval/?utm_source=chatgpt.com "Image to Image Retrieval using CLIP embedding and ... - LlamaIndex"
    66	[6]: https://arxiv.org/html/2404.08767v1?utm_source=chatgpt.com "Bridging Image Segmentation and Large Language Model Reasoning"
    67	[7]: https://llamaindexxx.readthedocs.io/en/latest/examples/multi_modal/image_to_image_retrieval.html?utm_source=chatgpt.com "Image to Image Retrieval using CLIP embedding and ... - LlamaIndex"
    68	[8]: https://github.com/run-llama/llama_index/issues/13985?utm_source=chatgpt.com "[Question]: How to write production grade code #13985 - GitHub"
